Poverty and inequality in France reach highest levels in 30 years
subhead: France's poverty rate reached 15.4% in 2023, its highest level since records began in 1996, according to data from the national statistics institute. The gap between the wealthiest and poorest 20% has widened, approaching levels last seen in the early 1970s.

title: How Israel tracked down and assassinated scientists involved in Iran's nuclear program
subhead: Israel's attacks in June killed 16 leading researchers involved in Iran's efforts to develop an atomic bomb. Some of them had been under Israeli intelligence surveillance for two decades. With their deaths, Israel believes it has dealt the most decisive blow yet to Tehran's military nuclear program.
byline: By Louis Imbert, Ghazal Golshiri and Liselotte Mas

title: In China, a 'black decade' for human rights lawyers
subhead: On July 9, 2015, Chinese authorities launched a sweeping crackdown on lawyers who dared to defend critics of the regime. 10 years later, the legal profession's room for maneuver has never been narrower.

title: From 'Amsterdam' to 'Ne me quitte pas,' Brel's songs take center stage in Avignon
subhead: At the Carrière de Boulbon, Anne Teresa De Keersmaeker, accompanied by Solal Mariotte, brings 26 classics by the Belgian singer to life through dance, sometimes risking an overly literal interpretation of their message.

title: In Greece, migrant registration sites 'have shifted from a jungle model to a prison model'
subhead: '2015-2025: Europe's migration crisis' (4/5). 'Hotspots,' originally conceived as migrant registration sites, have gradually turned into closed detention centers, such as on the island of Samos, where asylum seekers now live in isolation.
byline: By Julia Pascual (Samos (Greece), special correspondent) and Samuel Gratacap (Photos)

subhead: While local authorities hailed the decision, conservators warned of the risks of moving such a fragile work across the Channel.

title: ICRC head: 'Are we accepting life in a world where war is becoming the first resort?'
subhead: As battlefields multiply across the world, Pierre Krähenbühl, the director general of the International Committee of the Red Cross, laments the growing disregard for the laws of war set out in the Geneva Conventions.

title: Channel crossings by migrants in small boats are on the rise
subhead: Since the beginning of the year, more than 20,000 men, women and children have managed to reach the United Kingdom – 7,000 more than during the same period in 2024. At least 15 people have died while attempting the crossing.
byline: By Julia Pascual (Boulogne-sur-Mer, Dunkirk and Loon-Plage special correspondent)
